channel.title: Uncategorized on Sensr.net Blog | Watch your Stuff!
channel.description: Recent content in Uncategorized on Sensr.net Blog | Watch your Stuff!

item.title: The New Guy
item.description: Hello sensr.net users! I just wanted to take a moment to introduce myself to everyone; my name is Geoff and I am going to be working with sensr.net this summer. I will be writing a lot of blog posts as well as a number of other things. I look forward to helping you guys and being a part of this great community!

item.title: D-Link DCS-2230 FTP Problem Solved
item.description:
D-Link DCS 2230 doesn’t like empty FTP upload folder settings.

The DCS-2230 supports JPEG uploads via FTP. It turns out that it doesn’t like the upload folder set to / for some reason.  With Sensr.net we don’t care what you use for the upload folder name, we’ll take about anything or nothing.  But the DCS-2230 does seem to care.  Unless you put something into the folder field for the FTP uploads, it won’t work.

Thanks to a diligent Sensr.net user and DCS-2230 owner for letting us know!

Try it with your own DCS-2230 and let us know how it works.  Get your free Sensr.net trial and let us record your D-Link camera in the cloud.

item.title: Interactive Sensr.net Public Cameras Map
item.description:
Ever wonder where all the public cameras on Sensr.net are coming from, or just want to see some cool images from Australia or Hawaii? We’ve created an interactive public cameras map, allowing you to see where public cameras on Sensr.net are located. There are also links to each camera, making it easy to view any public camera based on locale. So if you’re curious about the geographic spread on Sensr.net, check it out! Play around with it and let us know what you think in the comments!

Keep in mind this map isn’t dynamic — it is a snapshot of our current active public cameras.

item.title: Best Network Cameras for Pets
item.description:
We’ve recently added a page on Sensr.net with our recommendations for the best network cameras around for keeping an eye on your pets, available at three price points.

On the Cheap: LOFTEK CXS 2200 – $68

Middle of the Road: Panasonic BL-C210A – $119

Getting Up There: Sharx VIPcella SCN2607 – $280

For a full description on why we chose these cameras, head over to our best network cameras for pets page.

item.title: Tulip’s Puppies Wigglin’ Around!
item.description: Check out the cute new clip of all the pups playing on the TulipCam – Thorn, Thistle, Huckleberry, Ash, and Cedar! For more about Tulip and her puppies, you can go to the Tails to Tell Animal Rescue Shelter website, http://tailstotell.ca. There you can also see an embedded live view of their TulipCam on Sensr.net!

item.title: Foscam at CES 2012
item.description:
2011 has been a fantastic year for Foscam – their flagship model, the FI8918W, has been crowned the fastest growing IP camera in the world, and is the number one selling network camera in the United States. And they’re unveiling some really awesome new models at this year’s Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas! If you’ve made it to Vegas for the event this year, you can go visit the Foscam team at booth 21931, South Hall Level 1.

To sweeten the deal a little more, Foscam is having a special CES 2012 sale at www.foscam.us, www.foscam.ca, and www.foscam.co.uk to celebrate the event! If you use the coupon code “CES2012” you’ll receive the discount.

item.title: Top 10 New Cameras for December 2011
item.description:
Here are the top 10 new cameras for December based on view count. These are all cameras added this month. They are all public, which means anyone can view them, including the archives.

Feel free to comment or make a clip if you find something interesting. I made the clip above, which was kind of intriguing.

  1. [
    Tweet

item.title: Loftek CXS 3200: Network Camera Deal of the Day
item.description:
LOFTEK’s replacement for the CXS 2200 is on sale for $79.99 on Amazon right now. The CXS 3200’s main improvement over its predecessor is its boasted “Trucolor” image processing technology, said to dramatically improve the netcam’s daytime colors. In low-light, the infrared filter is automatically disabled. In other specs, pan/tilt ranged were increased to 340º/100º, and the installation is supposed to be a lot easier, too. In case you don’t remember, setting up the LOFTEK CXS 2200 was a little wonky.

For only $10 more than the CXS 2200, it’s worth checking out the CXS 3200 for just the improved color, as that was one of my more major issues about the prior model. The Amazon specs also claim it not to  be on a static IP address, which is great too! If you’ve upgraded to the CXS 3200, let us know how it is, and get your camera up on Sensr.net!

item.title: Setting the Timezone on Your Sensr.net Camera
item.description:
When you add a camera to Sensr.net we ask for your timezone, but sometimes folks forget to set it. It defaults to America/Los Angeles because that’s the home time zone of Sensr.net.

If you want to change it, go to your camera page and click on the little gear in the upper right. Here’s a picture where I’ve circled the gear in red.

This gear opens the settings panel.

After you open the settings panel, you click the “Time Zone” pulldown under Camera Timezone and you can change the timezone for your camera. Now we’ll use that timezone when creating views for your camera, including the timestamp on the live view.

Here’s a shot of the timezone setting:

The red circle shows where to click to edit your camera's timezone.

Let us know if you have other questions!

item.title: Watch the Great British Beer Festival Live on Sensr.net!
item.description: [][1]The Great British Beer Festival is being streamed live on Sensr.net from August 2-6 in Earls Court, London. The event is Britain’s biggest beer festival, bringing together a wide range of real ales, ciders, perries, and international beers. You can watch all the action for the next few days, being shown on a Y-Cam Bullet. For more information on the festival’s beer lists, pub games, and much more, head on over to the Great British Beer Festival website.

item.title: Sensr.net: Facebook not required
item.description:
Our most frequent user request has been to drop the requirement of a Facebook account when adding cameras to Sensr.net.  Yesterday we released a new version of the site that implements this change, and a whole lot more.  You can now create a Sensr.net login using just an email and password.

_Note: Facebook isn’t gone, you can still link to your Facebook and Twitter accounts under my settings.    This will make it easier to share images and clips on Facebook and Twitter._

Existing Sensr.net Users

If you’re already a Sensr.net user (thanks), we’ve created an account for you using the email address linked to your Facebook account.  You just need to select a password.    Here’s how you do that.

  1.  Click the “login/sign up” link on the Sensr.net home page

  2.  Follow the link next to “have an account, never seen this page before”

If you used Facebook to log into Sensr.net before, follow the highlighted link

  1.  Authenticate with Facebook (one last time)

Authenticate with Facebook

  1.  Choose a password to go with your email

Choose a password

  1.  Success!

Successful account update

 

If you have any problems, click the feedback button and let us know.

item.title: Axis M1011 Firmware Upgrade for HTTP Upload
item.description:
Though a little used feature, Sensr.net support upload of images via HTTP. (Most of the cameras connected to the site use FTP.)  One of the few cameras that supports this upload option is the Axis M1011.

We had an Axis M1011 in the office that was presenting intermittent errors.  The system log in the camera reported the cryptic error:

Failed to read reply from server.

After poking around for a while, we checked the firmware revision and noticed that our camera had revision  of 5.00.1 dated December 2009. It turns out that there is a much newer revision of 5.20.1.  Installing this Firmware revision fixed the stability problem we were observing.

How to use HTTP Upload on the Axis M1011

Under the “Events” menu, define a new Event Server of type HTTP.  You will then be presented with a screen for defining the upload server.  HTTP Upload uses the same Sensr.net credentials as FTP Upload (SERVER/USERNAME/PASSWORD), but they are used in a slightly different way.

  • The Name can be anything meaningful to you.
  • The URL of the camera upload specifies the sensr upload server and the camera username:  http://SERVER/photo/USERNAME
  • The upload user name is the camera username: USERNAME
  • The upload password is the camera password: PASSWORD.

Now, define an event that will upload to this server.  I like to define an event to fire continuously at one-second intervals.  Use the Event Server name you created above to reference which server to connect to.  Notice how the event server called “NewHTTPServer” created above is reference here.

Conclusion

HTTP Upload is a simpler protocol than FTP and traverses firewalls better in some cases.  If you are using an Axis camera, you might like giving this option a try, but be sure to upgrade your firmware first.
